questions.question: What does democracy mean?
choices: All adults have a say in government
questions.explanation: Democracy means all adults can vote or choose representatives to make decisions.

questions.question: Who could vote in early 19th-century Britain?
questions.explanation: Only men over 21 who owned property could vote at that time.

questions.question: What was the name of the group that campaigned for voting reform in the 1830s and 1840s?
questions.explanation: The Chartists demanded six major democratic reforms in the 1830s–1840s.

questions.question: Which of these was NOT one of the Chartists' six demands?
questions.explanation: The Chartists focused on reforms for men; women's votes came later.

questions.question: When did most Chartist reforms become law?
questions.explanation: By 1918, most of the Chartists' demands had been introduced.

questions.question: When were women over 30 given the right to vote?
questions.explanation: Women over 30 gained the vote in 1918.

questions.question: In what year did men and women gain equal voting rights at age 21?
questions.explanation: In 1928, both men and women over 21 could vote.

questions.question: When was the UK voting age reduced to 18?
questions.explanation: In 1969, the voting age was lowered to 18.

questions.question: What is a constitution?
choices: A set of principles for governing a country
questions.explanation: A constitution sets the principles and structure of government.

questions.question: Why is the British constitution called 'unwritten'?
choices: It is not in a single document
questions.explanation: The British constitution exists in laws and traditions, not one written document.

questions.question: Which event has Britain NOT experienced compared to other countries?
questions.explanation: The UK has not had a revolution leading to a new government system like France or America.

questions.question: Who is the Head of State in the UK?
questions.explanation: King Charles III is the Head of State of the UK.

questions.question: What kind of monarchy does the UK have?
questions.explanation: The UK has a constitutional monarchy where the monarch's powers are limited by law.

questions.question: Who appoints the Prime Minister?
questions.explanation: The King invites the leader of the largest party to become Prime Minister.

questions.question: When did King Charles III become monarch?
questions.explanation: King Charles III became monarch in September 2022.

questions.question: Who is the heir to the British throne?
questions.explanation: Prince William, the Prince of Wales, is the heir to the throne.

questions.question: What is the National Anthem of the UK?
questions.explanation: ‘God Save the King’ is the UK’s National Anthem.

questions.question: What does the King do at the opening of Parliament?
choices: Gives a speech outlining government plans
questions.explanation: The King gives a speech summarising the government’s policies for the year.

questions.question: What is the King's role in Acts of Parliament?
choices: They are made in his name
questions.explanation: All Acts of Parliament are made in the King’s name.

questions.question: What do new British citizens promise during their citizenship ceremony?
choices: To be loyal to the King
questions.explanation: New citizens swear or affirm loyalty to King Charles III.
